_exec_summary.SummaryText:
EXECUTIVE SUMMARY
40 CFR 68.155(a)The Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies at the Stationary
Source

The stationary source covered by this Risk Management Plan is the Salt Valley Generating Station owned and
operated by the Lincoln Electric System (LES). LES is a municipally-owned and operated electric utility with
sole service responsibility in and around Lincoln, Nebraska. As a publicly owned utility, LES operates and
maintains all of the equipment in our system in a manner representing prudent utility practices and in
conformance with the expectations of LES customer/owner's. LES strives for excellence in the facility
operations and for full compliance with all local, state, and federal laws and regulations.

Meeting environmental requirements is part of LES policies and by developing and maintaining this Risk
Management Program LES is complying with the Federal Accident Prevention Provisions (40 CFR Part 68) and
the Risk Management Program defined in it. LES is committed to the accidental release prevention program.
LES maintains a thorough detailed Emergency Response Plan designated specifically for an ammonia release
for the Salt Valley Generating Station. The plan will be reviewed with response organizations and others.

40 CFR 68.155(b)The Stationary Source and Regulated Substance Handled
The LES Salt Valley Generating Station, owned and operated by LES, provides emergency, peaking and base
load electric power generation. There are three LM 6000 dual fuel aeroderivative combustion turbines located
on the 320-acre site; one of which operates in simple cycle, and two operate in either simple cycle or combined
cycle. The LM 6000 turbines are equipped with Selective Catalytic Reduction (SCR) for NOx emission control.
This system uses anhydrous ammonia which is fed into the exhaust combustion gases upstream of the SCR
catalyst modules.

Liquid anhydrous ammonia is stored in a pressure vessel under ambient temperature. The pressure vessel

has
a 12,000 gallon or 60,000 pound capacity with a maximum fill level at 85%. As the result, the normal operating
amount of ammonia stored in the Salt Valley Generating Station is 10,200 gallons or 51,000 pounds.
40 CFR 68.155(c)The Worst-Case Release Scenario(s) and the Alternative Release Scenario(s), Including
Administrative Controls and Mitigation Measures to Limit the Distances for Each Reported Scenario
Under the Risk Management Program, an oftisite consequence analysis is required for an accidental release of
a regulated substance. In Salt Valley Generating Station's case, anhydrous ammonia is the regulated
substance. Modeling of a worst-case release scenario and an alternative release scenario for anhydrous
ammonia are required for offsite consequence analysis under Program 2.

EPA has defined a worst-case release as the release of the largest quantity of a regulated substance from a
vessel that results in the greatest distance to a specified endpoint. The largest quantity is determined by taking
into account administrative controls that limit the quantity of a substance that can be stored or processed in a
vessel at any one time, or alternatively, procedures that occasionally allow the vessel to store greater than
usual quantities. EPA defined alternative release scenarios to be any release that is more likely to occur than
the worst-case scenario and that reaches an endpoint offsite.

For offsite consequence analysis, the movement and dispersion of a regulated substance release to the
atmosphere is predicted using the computer model called Areal Locations of Hazardous Atmosphere (ALOHA).
ALOHA predicts pollutant concentration downwind from the source, taking into consideration the physical
characteristics of ammonia, the physical characteristics of the site, weather condition, and the circumstance of
the release.

The worst case scenario selected for the Salt Valley Generating Station is the loss of 51,000 pounds of
pressurized anhydrous ammonia represent

ing a complete failure of the pressure vessel. The entire content of
the pressure vessel is released to the atmosphere within 10 minutes resulting in a release rate of 5,100
Ibslmin. Modeling results show that the worst-case scenario would have an offsite toxic endpoint of 1.1 miles.
The toxic endpoint is defined as the point where the ammonia concentration is below the level of concern.
which is 0.14 mglL or 200 ppm.

The alternative release scenario selected for the Salt Valley Generating Station is the release of 51,000 pounds
of pressurized anhydrous ammonia resulting from a failed connection on the pressure vessel. The entire
content of the pressure vessel is released to the atmosphere in 60 minutes resulting in a release rate of 850
Ibslmin. Modeling results show that the alternative release scenario would have an offsite toxic endpoint of
0.3 miles where the ammonia concentration drops below the level of concern of 0.14 mg/L or 200 ppm.

40 CFR 68.155(d) The General Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention
Steps

Salt Valley Generating Station has a Release Prevention Program in place to prevent accidental releases of
hazardous materials at this facility. The Release Prevention Program includes:

*Safety Information (SI)
LES developed and has kept current, working copies of SI documentation including information pertaining to
hazards of the process, the technology of the process and the equipment of the process. This information will
be used to inform employees and contractors.

*Hazard Review (HR)
LES is committed to performing HR to identify, evaluate and control hazards associated with Salt Valley
Generating Station's operation and to comply with the requirements of 40 CFR 68.50.
-Operating Procedures (OPs)
LES policy is to develop Salt Valley Generating Station OPs as required and to keep them current.

*Training
LES is committed to providing LES employees with comprehensive training to assure that the work force can
perform

their duties safely, efficiently and effectively.
-Maintenance
LES has developed a written maintenance program for the ammonia system at Salt Valley Generating Station.
The maintenance program includes pressure vessels and storage tanks, piping systems and ancillary
equipment, relief and vent systems and devices, emergency shutdown systems, controls and pumps.
Maintenance procedures are developed or promulgated by equipment vendors, federal or state regulations, or
industry codes.

*Incident lnvestigation
The current Lincoln Electric System Emergency Ammonia Release Response Plan for Salt Valley Generating
Station is a component of the lncident lnvestigation process. Incident reporting procedures are well defined.
Responsibilities, titles and phone numbers are given in a highly readable document.
40 CFR 668.155(e)The Five-Year Accident History
The five-year accident history involves an examination of the effects of any accidental releases of anhydrous
ammonia in the five years prior to the submission of a Risk Management Program. The five-year accident
history covers:

*A release of anhydrous ammonia from Salt Valley Generating Station that caused at least one of the following:
1.Onsite deaths, injuries, or significant property damage (40 CFR part 68.42(a)); or
2.Known offsite deaths, injuries, property damage, environmental damage, evacuations, or sheltering in place
(40 CFR part 68.42(a)).
There have been no releases from Salt Valley Generating Station that conform
with accidental release requirements that caused death, injuries, property damage, or environmental damage
either on or off site.

40 CFR 68.1 55(f)The Emergency Response Program
LES has a thorough detailed Emergency Ammonia Release Response Plan designated specifically for an
ammonia release for Salt Valley Generating Station. The plan will be reviewed with response organizations and
others.

40 CFR 68.155(g)Planned Changes to Improve Safety
LES will follow up on all of the recommendations in the recen

tly completed Risk Management Program in a
timely manner. Any recommendations resulting from the revalidation of the Risk Management Program in the
future will be dealt with in the same manner.
